citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Five wolves and one tiger have varying levels of hair loss and damage to the skin on the edges of the ears. Damage
includes thickened skin, scabs, and sores. Flies were seen landing on all of the animals’ ears. The animals were observed
shaking their heads and rubbing their ears. The facility representative states that the Attending Veterinarian has verbally
instructed them to use a variety of products for fly control both on the animals and in the environment. The licensee is
using “Vicks VapoRub” on the ears but none of the other treatments recommended by the AV.
Skin problems such as the above are most commonly caused by flies bites and can be painful. The licensee must use
appropriate methods to prevent, control and treat injuries. Additionally, the licensee must seek consultation with the
attending veterinarian for these animals' care.
To be corrected by seeking veterinary care for these animals by close of business on 7/2/2025

A public barrier was not present between two lemur enclosures and the viewing public. Barriers between non-human
primates and the public restrict physical contact. Barriers must be present between non-human primates and the public.
Correct by 1 Sept. 2025.

There was standing water and mud identified in one brown bear enclosure, one wolf enclosure, one hyena enclosure and
the warthog enclosure. The standing water in the bear and warthog enclosures were green with algae growth. The excess
water had turned the majority of the hyena and wolf enclosures into mud. Excess, standing water and mud in enclosures
can lead to an increase in the presence of pests, create odors and can soil the animals present in those enclosures.
Excess water must be rapidly eliminated from all enclosures. Correct by 15 July 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Margaret Shaver, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Five wolves and one tiger have varying levels of hair loss and damage to the skin on the edges of the ears. Damage 
includes thickened skin, scabs, and sores. Flies were seen landing on all of the animals’ ears. The animals were observed 
shaking their heads and rubbing their ears. The facility representative states that the Attending Veterinarian has verbally 
instructed them to use a variety of products for fly control both on the animals and in the environment. The licensee is 
using “Vicks VapoRub” on the ears but none of the other treatments recommended by the AV. 
Skin problems such as the above are most commonly caused by flies bites and can be painful. The licensee must use 
appropriate methods to prevent, control and treat injuries. Additionally, the licensee must seek consultation with the 
attending veterinarian for these animals' care.  
To be corrected by seeking veterinary care for these animals by close of business on 7/2/2025 
3.78(e) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
A public barrier was not present between two lemur enclosures and the viewing public. Barriers between non-human 
primates and the public restrict physical contact. Barriers must be present between non-human primates and the public. 
Correct by 1 Sept. 2025. 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There was standing water and mud identified in one brown bear enclosure, one wolf enclosure, one hyena enclosure and 
the warthog enclosure. The standing water in the bear and warthog enclosures were green with algae growth. The excess 
water had turned the majority of the hyena and wolf enclosures into mud. Excess, standing water and mud in enclosures 
can lead to an increase in the presence of pests, create odors and can soil the animals present in those enclosures. 
Excess water must be rapidly eliminated from all enclosures. Correct by 15 July 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

Additional Inspectors: 
Margaret Shaver, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
GRAY WOLF / GREY WOLF / TIMBER WOLF
